title: Crunch time for ‘AKK’ in east Germany
text:
BERLIN — Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer is going East.

The leader of Germany’s Christian Democrats and heir apparent to Angela Merkel will head to Germany’s eastern states this week ahead of a pair of regional elections that could determine her political future.

Brandenburg, a Social Democratic bastion that surrounds Berlin, and Saxony, a state the Christian Democrats have governed since German reunification, are up for grabs and the CDU is expected to suffer heavy losses in both. Kramp-Karrenbauer’s challenge in the final days of the campaign will be to limit the losses and, crucially, defend the CDU’s first place position in Saxony.

For Kramp-Karrenbauer, who both grew up and built her political career in the far reaches of western Germany, the former territories of the German Democratic Republic are almost foreign territory. Nonetheless, if the CDU, which Kramp-Karrenbauer has led since December, loses substantial ground there, the “East” — as Germans still refer to the former GDR — could put a quick end to her hopes of becoming Germany’s next chancellor.

A poor result would fuel a debate over whether “AKK,” Kramp-Karrenbauer’s preferred moniker, has what it takes to be chancellor. Following a series of political missteps in recent months, some in the party are already asking that question.

The problems began in March, when a toilet joke Kramp-Karrenbauer made during a Karneval event was perceived by some as homophobic. Then, after the CDU suffered major losses in the European Parliament election, she accused a young German YouTube personality who scored a smash hit with a video critical of the CDU of manipulating public opinion. To make matters worse, she suggested such content should be censored in the future, opening her up to criticism that she wants to place controls on free speech.

Meantime, the law-and-order rhetoric Kramp-Karrenbauer began using on issues such as migration, meant to help shore up the CDU’s right wing and stem the rise of the populist Alternative for Germany (AfD), backfired by pushing moderate CDU voters to the Greens. The Greens have shot up several percentage points in national polls since Kramp-Karrenbauer took over the CDU to pull neck and neck with the center-right party. Though much of the Greens' support comes from disgruntled former Social Democrats, the party is also drawing a substantial number of votes from the CDU, according to recent exit poll data.

Her stumbles as party chief prompted Merkel to tap Kramp-Karrenbauer as defense minister last month following Ursula von der Leyen’s nomination as European Commission president. The high-profile defense portfolio would offer Kramp-Karrenbauer a perfect opportunity to prove her mettle, Merkel argued.

Down on Merkel

So far, the surprise appointment has only increased the scrutiny of Kramp-Karrenbauer’s every move.

The main reason for that decline has little to do with Kramp-Karrenbauer, but everything to do with her political mentor — Merkel.

That’s why she has so much riding on the East, and particularly on Saxony.

While the latest polls suggest the CDU still has a comfortable lead, with 31 percent, compared with 25 percent for the second-placed AfD, the conservatives have lost more than one-fifth of their support since 2014. An AfD victory would be unprecedented, marking the first time the party has finished first in a regional election (even if it wins, the party is unlikely to govern because the other major parties have ruled out a coalition with the far-right group).

The main reason for that decline has little to do with Kramp-Karrenbauer, but everything to do with her political mentor — Merkel. Merkel’s refugee policies are particularly unpopular in Saxony and other eastern states, where many people worry that the new arrivals will change Germany’s culture and sap federal resources.

Dresden, the state capital, is the birthplace of PEGIDA, an anti-refugee protest movement that spawned weekly demonstrations against “Islamization” across Germany. During an event to celebrate German reunification in 2016 in the city, Merkel was heckled as a Volksverräter, a traitor to the German “Volk.”

German state election campaigns usually revolve around local questions, but in Saxony, which has suffered a burst of racial violence over the past couple of years, the national has become local. Both Merkel’s migration policy and her government’s plan to end coal-fired electricity generation, which will hit Saxony’s coal-mining region, have dominated the campaign.

Though the state has done quite well since reunification — unemployment is under 6 percent and both Dresden and Leipzig are booming — many people fear that Merkel’s policies, in particular migration, could jeopardize their economic progress. Worries about falling down the socio-economic ladder are particularly pronounced in the East, where many families were hit hard by the dislocation triggered by reunification.

Michael Kretschmer, Saxony’s Christian Democrat premier, has sought to subtly distance himself from the chancellor by changing the subject.

“If you make your decision a political protest against 2015 and Frau Merkel you’ll achieve nothing, ” he told an audience on the campaign trail last week, referring to Merkel’s 2015 decision to keep Germany’s border open to refugees. “This is about Saxony.”

Soul of the CDU

Kramp-Karrenbauer’s close association with Merkel is just one reason she’s been a rare sight on the campaign trail until now.

In an open letter in June, local CDU officials accused Kramp-Karrenbauer of “arrogance” in her treatment of the East. The officials took umbrage with Kramp-Karrenbauer’s public criticism of Kretschmer for meeting with Russian leader Vladimir Putin and accused her of lacking sensitivity for the East’s long connection with Russia.

Kramp-Karrenbauer sought to mend fences in a pair of private meetings with her critics. But the tensions broke into the open again last week after she said that Hans-Georg Maaßen, the former head of the Germany’s domestic intelligence service, didn’t belong in the CDU.

Maaßen was forced to resign as intelligence chief after a series of controversial remarks, including publicly questioning Merkel’s characterization of a racially motivated attack caught on video in the city of Chemnitz last year as a coordinated manhunt.

Maaßen’s dismissal made him a hero in right-wing circles in the CDU, including in Saxony, where he has been a sought-after guest speaker at local campaign events.

Asked during a newspaper interview last week whether she thought Maaßen should be thrown out of the party, Kramp-Karrenbauer responded: “There are high hurdles for expelling someone from the party, and for good reason. But when it comes to Mr. Maaßen’s attitude, I don’t see anything that really connects him with CDU.”

Instead of talking about train travel, the defense minister has been on the defensive.

Though she didn’t call for Maaßen’s removal, her comments were taken as major provocation by the conservative wing of the party who see the CDU as a Volkspartei, a big tent party that should be accommodate a range of views. Even Kramp-Karrenbauer’s supporters criticized her, complaining that her comments did nothing but elevate Maaßen’s standing.

The comments overshadowed what should have been a notable political victory for Kramp-Karrenbauer last week: her success in introducing free rail travel for German soldiers, a move meant to improve moral in the country's armed forces.

Instead of talking about train travel, the defense minister has been on the defensive. Even a week after the Maaßen comments, she continues to face questions over what she really meant.

Kramp-Karrenbauer's response has been that she doesn’t want to “betray the soul of the party” by embracing the right-wing positions espoused by Maaßen.

If the CDU loses Saxony, she'll stand accused of an even greater betrayal.

description: The conservatives struggle to keep Saxony, an eastern German state where Merkel’s refugee policy is deeply unpopular.
